stream_context.summary: The stream focused on developing assets for Course 11, an oil rig level. Key activities included creating and programming new platform behaviors, debugging a major zipline regression bug, implementing a new global lighting system, and collaboratively refining the level's color palette with community feedback. The session also included a review of a new Bowser animation by Zeina and testing on N64 hardware.

development_findings.summary: The poor performance of the 'Wario's Wildlife World' (The Zoo) level was the direct catalyst for Kaze undertaking the massive project of optimizing the entire SM64 engine.
development_findings.quote: The zoo is actually the reason I even started optimizing Mario 64. The zoo ran so poorly that I just could not take that.

development_findings.summary: A new lighting system inspired by Super Mario Odyssey was implemented, adding a camera-based light to illuminate Mario and moving objects, improving readability in dark areas.
development_findings.quote: Basically, I added the light coming from the camera back... In addition to the normal level light, which makes the whole game look a lot brighter.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is replacing the standard N64 library, libultra, with his own custom, optimized version, which he suspects is the cause of some new rendering bugs like the broken cannon reticle.
development_findings.quote: See what I did is, we don't use libultra anymore, I'm making my own optimized libultra.

development_findings.summary: The oil rig level (Course 11) is thematically and visually inspired by Rico Harbor from Super Mario Sunshine, even using recolored textures from that game.
development_findings.quote: Rico Harbor is a little bit the inspiration for this level.

development_findings.summary: Progress on the Buzzer boss fight is currently stalled, as Kaze is waiting on animations from Zeina, such as the Bowser walk cycle.
The team collaboratively refined the level's color palette from a confusing red/orange to a purple/yellow/blue scheme to establish a clearer identity and atmosphere.
The retro pipe for Course 11 will lead to a stage based on 'Board the Platforms' from Super Smash Bros. 64.
Kaze plans to use a two-week vacation from his job to potentially implement split-screen multiplayer.
development_findings.quote: My company actually gives me a lot of money for this. It gives me two weeks vacation at the end of June. And in those two weeks, I might add multiplayer. With split-screen.

development_findings.summary: A regression bug that broke all ziplines was traced back to a collision optimization Kaze made months prior and had never tested, which he fixed live on stream.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a design philosophy that developers should make firm decisions about core mechanics rather than providing player-toggled options.
context_findings.quote: I'm kind of against giving players options. I think it's weird to give the player an option to like select how the fundamental thing like that works.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes games should foster player freedom and decision-making, and avoids hand-holding mechanics like trajectory guides for cannons.
context_findings.quote: I think games should be about experiencing freedom. Am I giving you the line to move along? You don't have any freedom. You're just kind of following instructions.

context_findings.summary: He believes game designers must account for player misinterpretation, citing the oil rig's liquid being mistaken for lava as a reason to change its color for clarity.
context_findings.quote: Too many people are stupid. Well, you have to account for that as a designer. People are going to play your game. And if people are stupid, then you have to account for stupid people playing your game.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has permanently switched from streaming on Twitch to YouTube, citing Twitch's aggressive and unskippable ad policy, even for paying subscribers, as the primary reason.
context_findings.quote: I find it personally unwatchable with all the ads. Because on YouTube, at least I can decide whether there's ads or not.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shared a personal anecdote from first grade where he made a classmate cry by telling her salami is made from horses, reflecting a mischievous personality.
context_findings.quote: I told her, did you know that they make salami out of horses? And she just started to cry.

context_findings.summary: He intentionally inserted factual errors into a recent YouTube video (e.g., claiming SM64 was the first 3D platformer) as an experiment to drive algorithm engagement via correction comments, but noted it was not very successful.
Kaze expressed a dislike for playing chess, finding it feels like unpaid work and suffering.
context_findings.quote: I know chess is one of those weird things where I like the idea of being good at it but actually playing it literally just feels like work I'm not being paid for.

biobak.summary: Biobak was credited with the initial idea for the oil rig's red liquid color, which was later changed after being widely misinterpreted as lava.
biobak.quote: That was Biobak's idea. I'm innocent.

biobak.summary: A specific color, "bio-back pink", was referenced during the stream, suggesting Biobak has a recognizable artistic style or color preference known to the team.

badub.summary: Badub is the composer of the 'Koopa's Revenge 2' soundtrack used in the stream, which consists of original music and some remixes of Mario songs.
badub.quote: All of the OST is custom made by Badub. So, it actually is not copyrighted. Well, actually, there are some remixes of Mario songs.

zeina.summary: Zeina created a new walk cycle animation for Bowser from scratch and presented it during the stream for feedback.
zeina.quote: Just for the fun of it, I duplicated the other animation and tried to do it from scratch.

zeina.summary: Zeina expressed that while she sometimes likes being on stream, she generally prefers participating from the chat.
zeina.quote: I mean, truth be told, I prefer being in the chat. It's more fun.

zeina.summary: Zeina revealed she gets paid to play Fortnite as part of a team-building activity at her professional job.
zeina.quote: Look, I'm literally paid to play Fortnite. I have a good excuse. I'm a professional gamer.

zeina.summary: She and Kaze discussed the technical constraints of the Bowser animation, agreeing to omit head movement so that Bowser's head can be programmatically aimed at Mario in-game.

key_stories.title: The Untested Optimization
key_stories.summary: When a core mechanic was found to be broken, the ensuing bug hunt revealed it was caused by an untested optimization Kaze had implemented months earlier. The incident offered a stark look into his high-risk, high-reward development style, where he prioritizes speed over comprehensive testing.
key_stories.challenge: A fundamental gameplay mechanic, the zipline, was discovered to be completely broken throughout the game when Kaze tried to implement one in a new level.
key_stories.process: Kaze began debugging by confirming the issue in another level. He then used a combination of print statements and a makeshift breakpoint (crashing the game intentionally) to trace the execution flow. This led him to the ceiling-finding function, where he recalled making an untested optimization months earlier and quickly spotted the error.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully identified the bug as a single misplaced bracket in his untested collision optimization code from months ago. He fixed it within minutes, restoring the zipline functionality and providing a candid example of his development philosophy.
key_stories.key_quote: See that's the thing with me. I never test my code. I just assume it works. And it saves me a lot of time. And usually it does. And sometimes, months later, a bug just occurs and it's like, yeah, now I have to prove that I didn't mess up. And I just did.

key_stories.title: The Lighting Revelation
key_stories.summary: After noting the game looked too dark, Kaze implemented a new global lighting feature inspired by Mario Odyssey. By adding a light source tied to the camera, he was able to make the player character more visible, enabling more dramatic and atmospheric lighting design.
key_stories.challenge: The game was receiving feedback that it looked too dark, making it difficult to see Mario and read the action in shadowy environments.
key_stories.process: Inspired by watching footage of Super Mario Odyssey, Kaze decided to add a new light source to the engine. He coded a light that is attached to the game camera and specifically illuminates dynamic objects like Mario, supplementing the level's static directional light.
key_stories.outcome: The new camera-based light dramatically improved visual clarity, making Mario 'pop' from the background. This allowed Kaze to use darker ambient lighting and deeper shadows for atmosphere without sacrificing playability, a result he was extremely happy with.
key_stories.key_quote: The new lighting is so cool we can add such deep shadows you see that shit? It looks really good.

key_stories.title: The Oil Rig's Identity Crisis
key_stories.summary: The oil rig level's color scheme was causing confusion, as its red liquid was mistaken for lava. This prompted a collaborative redesign on stream, showcasing the process of adapting design based on player feedback to improve clarity and atmosphere.
key_stories.challenge: The liquid in the oil rig level was colored red and orange, causing many playtesters and viewers to misinterpret it as dangerous lava, which was not the intention.
key_stories.process: Kaze acknowledged the design flaw on stream, stating the need to design for player perception. He then began live experimentation, soliciting feedback from Zeina and the chat as he tested different color combinations for the liquid, scaffolding, and fog to find a more fitting and less confusing aesthetic.
key_stories.outcome: After live experimentation, the team settled on a palette of royal purple, yellow, and blue. Kaze felt this new combination was more visually rich, unique, and effectively solved the communication problem, giving the level a stronger identity.
key_stories.key_quote: Too many people think it's burning ash or lava. So I do see an issue there... You have to account for that as a designer.
